The occasion also contained an international conference on Slavic literature in France. During the conference there were many discussions on the ways in which the Serbian and Croatian literary traditions could serve as a bridge for the European literary project. The most significant among them was the conference held on 14-15th January 1959, in Paris between Srdja Trifunovic, the literary critic and leader of the Slovene Renaissance, and Jadranka Lajeva (later president-designate of the Council of Europe).

The Slovene Renaissance was a political movement and it took an active part in the formation of a new Slovenia. It was strongly in favour of the "cultural autonomy" of Slovenia, its independence from central authority.

original: Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. While the scheduling formula is not as rigid for preseason games as they are for the regular season, there are numerous restrictions and traditions that limit the choices of preseason opponents; teams are also restricted on what days and times they can play these games. Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. For instance, the Philadelphia Eagles begin the first preseason game on Thursday, April 13, and finish the fourth preseason game on Sunday, April 20.

The 2016 NFL preseason schedule was released on November 27, 2016, and it will likely serve as a reminder of what the teams will be facing next year

The palace was one of the most important monuments of ancient Egypt and the largest single building in a single country. The palace was considered one of the greatest architectural achievements of ancient Egypt. It was built so as to present a single uninterrupted facade that was flanked on three sides by three massive columns. The facade contained the main frieze and the main entrance. The main frieze opened onto a high staircase that went down into a basement where the central statue of Hathor sat, flanked by four Hathor statues and an eagle. But by 1994, Libya's economy had become virtually nonexistent. In 1991 just 10 percent of Libyans owned property. By 1994 just 6 percent did.

original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage is the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aids in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between populations and species is one of the primary means of differentiation among mammals.

Some mammals have a large number of hairs on one side of the face, such as the mouse. Such a hair appears on the face of one or both sides of the upper lip, under the chin, and is arranged in a ring around the eyes. The hairs are dark in color and are usually small. A few mammals such as the rhesus macaque, an important research model, have very few hair follicles on one side of the face, the eyebrows.

completed: Mammalian hair , also known as pelage , can vary in color between populations , organisms within a population , and even on the individual organism . original: Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents are more open to 'trying on' different behaviours and appearances to discover who they are. In other words, in an attempt to find their identity and discover who they are adolescents are liking to cycle through a number of identities to find one that suits them best. But, developing and maintaining identity (in adolescent years) is a difficult task due to multiple factors such as family life, environment, and social status. Empirical studies suggest that this process might be more accurately described as identity development, rather than formation, but confirms a normative process of change in both content and structure of one's thoughts about the self. The two main aspects of identity development are self-clarity and self-esteem. Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents begin to ask probing questions and attempt to find an answer. As adolescents grow to develop into adults, the desire to have an identity becomes increasingly important.

As we move past adolescence and continue on into our adult years, identity development becomes even more important. We all strive to find what we are, and for most of us this quest will take many trips to the identity doctor and then a journey through numerous phases of denial.

For example, if you look back at some of your adolescent years, you might have been caught up in denial or confusion and felt that you didn't know. completed: Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are developing their own identities and are also making decisions about where they wish to spend the rest of their lives in the future . Although adolescents are trying to make sense of their lives , teens are still making many of their decisions by comparison with others . Teenagers may compare themselves with others based on how they match with their peers , what they do and do n't want to look like , or how they are treated . The way teens are evaluated by others , including their parents , may affect their decision about whether or not to develop a different identity than they think is possible or what they may choose to do in the future . Adolesc ence is a transit ory and so may develop different identities according to how they are perceived by their peers .

Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. In most Jewish populations, these founder events probably represent, at best, a very small subset of all the Jews. If they did represent a larger fraction (by 50%) of all the Jews, the most ancient Jewish ancestors likely began to appear about 10,000 years ago in Africa, with a substantial fraction of the Jewish gene pool coming from about 100,000 years ago (see Figure 1). This is somewhat less than the age of the first Jewish men from sub-Saharan Africa, so the evidence does not support the picture of a new migration from Africa to Europe and back. However, the new results add to the evidence for an ancient Jewish migration, and they help to eliminate the possibility that the most ancient Jews were a people who began their spread and admixture around the time of the Exodus (12,500 years ago).

completed: Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths . In most Jewish populations , these founders are small, in some cases no more than one or possibly two persons . Therefore , the most reasonable conclusion must be that only one tribe or sub group of the Jewish people actually gave birth to Judaism . .. Jewish DNA studies have also led some Jews to argue that the Jewish people originated either in Judea or the Galilee . Both these claims are not supported by the evidence from the DNA studies , which indicate that only one Jewish tribe or subgroup gave birth to Judaism . The only remaining explanation is that the Jewish people are simply a genetic hybrid of many other peoples . original: Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening and (with exception of the ostrich) uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste. However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, rather than creatinine like mammals. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by joining cloaca, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate pellets. They presume that racial preferences do not promote racism in an analogous manner to the effects of race -conscious policies in the context of racial discrimination . By contrast , proponents of race -neutral public policies assume that it is possible to devise policies , including race -neutral policies , that do not foster discrimination. Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus or minus one, while PAL-specification discs could carry three analog audio tracks, plus or minus two.

Sound was stored in the sound device. Audio signals were transmitted directly to the sound device and then encoded into a standard bit stream, which could then be decoded at the sound device. The signal could be stored on a magnetic disk or recorded on to a phonograph disc.

Because of the way these machines stored sound, some sources such as a tape may be better than others. For example, a phonograph may sound better than vinyl on some types of recordings. Also, a tape will retain more information than any other medium. For example, the sounds from many recordings might require many times more information than music available in a compact disc.

The Institute was instrumental in initiating studies of healthy development, in contrast to previous work that had been dominated by theories based on pathological personalities. The Oakland Growth Study, initiated by Harold Jones and Herbert Stolz in 1931, aimed to study the physical, intellectual, and social development of children in the Oakland area. Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 American Psychological Association Award for distinguished service to psychology, as well as the 1993 American Psychological Association Women's Leadership Award.

Through its programs and fellowships, the Institute supports graduate students and undergraduate scholars in human development with opportunities for research, teaching and research training. The Institute also supports the graduate and professional schools, libraries and archives of the University of California, Berkeley.

completed: Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California , Berkeley 's Institute of Human Development , formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare , in 1927 . The Institute was instrumental in shaping U.C . Berkeley 's child welfare policy over the next forty years . It is the largest institution offering professional development in the field of child welfare and served as the model for the National Committee on the Education of the Handicapped .  Macfarlane was also a pioneer in child psychotherapy throughout the state of California . He was an early advocate for psychotherapy in public health and for the rights of children .  Mac farlane 's life was remarkable for his remarkable accomplishments and his dedication to public service . He was the first psychoan alyst in Berkeley , the first child welfare director of the U .C . Berkeley ' s Institute of Human Development , and a staunch advocate for the rights of children . He dedicated his life to helping children , their families and their foster homes .

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe had been devastated by war and its post-war political and social upheavals. Yet the British remained deeply committed to empire, as did most of the European countries. Although Britain had never won a war on home soil, she had been at least as successful at projecting power. Britain's military and economic might provided the United States with a new base to project its imperial ambitions upon. In a similar vein, the emotions and disorders theory proposes that there are emotions and disorders which result from the complex interconnections among the three dimensions of emotions described thus far. Although not necessarily exclusive, there is growing evidence in the literature to suggest that, in some cases, only one of the dimensions of emotions is considered important within the field.

Estonia will continue to rely on Russia for gas supplies, which means its transition to a market economy will remain lengthy, but it will allow the economy to begin to diversify into new regions. It will become a hub for IT services and high-tech manufacturing. original: Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A sample taken from potentially diseased tissue or fluid is then tested for the presence of an infectious agent able to grow within that medium. Most pathogenic bacteria are easily grown on nutrient agar, a form of solid medium that supplies carbohydrates and proteins necessary for growth of a bacterium, along with copious amounts of water. A single bacterium will grow into a visible mound on the surface of the plate called a colony, which may be separated from other colonies or melded together into a "lawn". The size, color, shape and form of a colony is characteristic of the bacterial species, its specific genetic makeup (its strain), and the environment that supports its growth. The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced the notion of natural selection - the idea that traits are inherited by descent. However, many modern-day Americans think of race as hereditary, with specific genetic differences between different races. People have been fascinated by claims that whites have evolved white skin through the process of selective breeding, while East Asians often have dark skin due to the fact that they had darker skin in their original homeland. original: The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), for supremacy in spaceflight capability. It had its origins in the missile-based nuclear arms race between the two nations that occurred following World War II, enabled by captured German rocket technology and personnel. The two parts overlap , and if they are too close together , the crop may get wet , the weather is colder , the soil dri es out , the weeds begin to grow , and the yield is lower than it could be , even if sufficient rain occurs during the first part of the autumn . That is why , farmers must use irrigation in accordance with their ability , and in the early autumn, when the harvest is underway , they increase irrigation , which then increases the yield , and at the same time makes it possible to prevent any loss of the crop .

In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the phrase le bataillon-carré ('square battalion'). In the bataillon-carré system, the various corps of the Grande Armée would march uniformly together in close supporting distance. If any single corps was attacked, the others could quickly spring into action and arrive to help. Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 troops, rapidly marching on the right bank of the River Saale. As in previous campaigns, his fundamental objective was to destroy one opponent before reinforcements from another could tip the balance of the war. original: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a marker that imposes restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people are ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary will also impose restrictions on the people it has included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. Some people may understand the language used by this person while others may not. original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

original: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. completed: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing , sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated . This is achieved by Neutral Sections ( also known as Neutral Stacks ) of appropriate length. In an electrically isolated system the DC power to each station must be the same ; otherwise voltage differences between the two feeds cause current to flow at the Neutral Section resulting in a lower output voltage and higher current density . In most applications where the isolated section is a neutral section of larger diameter the neutral section is connected in series with a high wattage load in order to ensure a low resist ive load . For more information on Neutral Sections please refer to the Neutral Section Page . The other section of the circuit ( the feed ers ) contain the normal DC loads plus capac itors and resistor s to ensure that the power consumed by the neutral -channel section is sufficient to meet the overall output requirements of the system .

In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the loss of the Great Charter following a series of rebellions, Penn continued to seek new tracts of land. With the help of Pennsylvania legislators, like the Honorable Nathaniel Bradford, he acquired two tracts near Plymouth and another near Philadelphia.

The Treaty of London on April 29, 1691 placed responsibility for paying the debts of the Dutch colony with the French colony. The payment was intended to satisfy the colonists who had protested against payment. After a series of violent raids, in 1692 Penn agreed to cede to the settlers in his lands four of the eight parcels that had been ceded by his predecessor.

In 1693 Penn signed the Treaty of Paris. The next year, Penn's father, Sir John Penn, was born in Holland. The Penns came to North America later that year, sailing from England with the first colonists.

original: Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. Moulting is annual in most species, although some may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, flight feathers are replaced one at a time with the innermost primary being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage".

The feathers on the head and flanks, the talons and the beak (gizzard) are all considered part of the pre-breeding plumage and so must be removed, and sometimes a part of a bird that has moulted must be preserved to protect itself from predation.

It is thought that after breeding the sexes develop different plumage, because in early development, all other parts of the bird are covered with the same feather cells.

However, not all parts of the plumage are equally important in survival. The beak is thought to be one of the most important parts in pre-breeding plumage because of the importance of a beak to feeding, and to helping a bird keep a balance in balance between itself and the environment.

original: As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are oxidizers (i.e., acceptors of electrons) and some react very strongly. For the continued normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, these free radicals must be sufficiently neutralized by antioxidant compounds. Recently, some researchers suggested an interesting theory of evolution of dietary antioxidants. Some are produced by the human body with adequate precursors (glutathione, Vitamin C), and those the body cannot produce may only be obtained in the diet via direct sources (Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, Vitamin K) or produced by the body from other compounds (Beta-carotene converted to Vitamin A by the body, Vitamin D synthesized from cholesterol by sunlight). Phytochemicals (Section Below) and their subgroup, polyphenols, make up the majority of antioxidants; about 4,000 are known. Different antioxidants are now known to function in a cooperative network. The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical reality had very different implications from statements about mental objects. Physical states are no longer simply mental objects on which to pin our attention, but are rather something much deeper to be looked at in terms of what it means for a set of statements to be true or false. For instance, statements about the motion of a ship cannot be regarded as true or false because motion does not occur at all in the mind and no laws or relationships exist to connect a thought about motion with the actual motion of the ship itself.

Despite the growing appreciation of the fundamental difference between physical and mental states of affairs, the phenomenalist, despite being generally a naturalist, felt a sort of hesitance to drop his metaphysics in response to physicalism. original: Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that dates to 8700 BC. There is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) were the only metals used by humans before copper. The history of copper metallurgy is thought to have followed the following sequence: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax method. In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these metallurgical techniques appears more or less simultaneously at the beginning of the Neolithic c. 7500 BC. However, just as agriculture was independently invented in several parts of the world, copper smelting was invented locally in several different places. The most interesting thing about copper is the amount of copper it contains, and the fact that it is a metal with a fairly high melting point. Copper is a metal with an extremely large amount of energy stored in it, and the heat produced during the melting process can be used to create electricity. One of the reasons why the Romans used copper rather than iron for their weapons was the fact that copper held a higher thermal conductivity compared to iron. A high heat transfer coefficient allowed more heat to be carried away in one direction, making the metal the ideal choice for weapons.

The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on farms, on islands and even through the mail), so this is not just a concern for the species themselves, but for species that we depend on for food, such as some bird species. They may not always do well in new habitats, and they can also encounter human health hazards, such as antibiotic-resistant diseases. The increase in number of invasions is a cause for concern not only for those that are impacted by these organisms, but also for a wide range of organisms that use the same water for their survival.

Why are we seeing such big numbers of species invasions across all types of habitats? The situation varies on a species level, with some species going through a burst of new invaders and others recovering from decades of sustained low numbers. How can I reduce the number of invasions I'm seeing in my local areas?
completed: The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s . Species are increasingly being moved by humans ( on purpose and unintentionally ) in order to increase agricultural productivity or create habitats for themselves or for other species . The expansion of monocult ures has an impact on biodiversity through the introduction of new species , which may compete with native species . However , invasive species , when present in numbers sufficient in time , do not represent a danger to biodiversity and there is an extensive literature that reviews the risks posed by invasive species , including their interactions with other species . The biodiversity loss generated by invasions is generally thought to be lower than biodiversity loss caused by species loss. The ecological significance of species losses is controversial , however . While invasive species are a current threat , species losses are usually thought to result in local extinction . This is because many of the species that are lost are rarely recovered ;

After reaching the Italian side of Lake Geneva , Napoleon ordered Gen Joseph Joseph Moreau de Bellièvre to mount a quick assault on the Austrian position at a monastery on the lake shore . Once the attack began , a large Austrian infantry unit under Lt Col Grazier von Asfelden turned around and marched for home , abandoning the army to its fate in the mountains along the lake shore . It was an epic battle that ended in the Austrian victory and the beginning of the Hundred Days . The Austrian soldiers then fled the field, leaving behind many of their uniforms .

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the huge advances made throughout the century, the technology remained somewhat inefficient. The phonautographer was expensive, prone to malfunction and would require manual adjustments due to the poor quality of microphones and speaker combinations.

In 1927, J. P. Morgan and J. W. Carnegie had the idea to combine Edison's invention with other new technologies to create the first commercial computer. To create a sound recording of the same length as a human voice, a two-inch tape was mounted with a microphone to record audio with the voice. Using a reel-to-reel player, players would play a record using an electromagnet, which would rotate the tape along with the needle, resulting in recording sound. At this level of performance, the record could be sent across the radio frequency transmission spectrum by radio receivers, effectively creating a computer.

In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12 hours of footage each night. This was called the "Midnight Special."

In a way, it's the classic recording for its time. Though Gabler uses a more technical approach than many sound men of the time, he still makes interesting use of the microphones and his own vocal stylings to create a story and, most importantly, capture the essence of the events taking place. There is a great deal of tension and mystery built into each recording. Here, he is in a small cottage; a very dangerous place to be at night. One minute he's out front; the next, up inside his own home. There's lots of very tense moments of negotiation, some shouting and much shouting. Most memorable is a shot of a woman screaming; an event that is of great importance to the characters in Gabler's stories.

completed: A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment , including Deism and talk of atheism . Deism , according to Thomas Paine , is the simple belief that God is all- powerful and that all the world 's religions were just attempts to reach that reality . In contrast with the Christian and Islamic gods , Deists believe that there is a force of nature beyond the world and a reason for life besides God . Their God is not an external being and not the author or ultimate cause of life , but a creative force or 'causeless cause .
